timeline.bodyText:
Can this message be replaced by using the debugger or by increasing the framework's log level? See point 4 https://www.openhab.org/docs/developer/guidelines.html#f-logging
Same for below.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure this needs to be started?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You should call the base class destructor at the end of the method.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Does the state matter, when the Thing is disposed? Can this be removed?
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Bindings should only log to error, when something really severe happened. In this case you could put the message as an argument to the updateStatus() invocation. This is logged by the framework and shown in the UI.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could give the user a hint what went wrong. See above.
timeline.author: fwolter
fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You could cache the config in initialize(), since this invocation is quite expensive.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure this method is needed? If the config is updated dispose()/initialize() are called.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure this method is needed? If the bridge goes offline, its child Things are updated, too.
timeline.author: fwolter

timeline.bodyText: You might want to handle the refresh command.
timeline.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: Yes i want but not an the moment. Handle command is the next step

timeline.bodyText: Please handle the REFRESH-command directly or indirectly via some cache. It prevents situations were people link an additional channel after the binding was already started. It will make sure that they don't have to wait until the next cycle for the data to be populated.

timeline.bodyText:
I think it might be dangerous to annotate your JSON classes like this, it gives a false sense of security. GSON will not validate the null-ness of the fields. And I don't know whether your bases it on some documentation but even that is not guaranteed to remain as is.
@cpmeister what do you think of this?
timeline.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: If i do so, i think i got a warning.
replies.author: EvilPingu

replies.bodyText:
I think it might be dangerous to annotate your JSON classes like this, it gives a false sense of security. GSON will not validate the null-ness of the fields. And I don't know whether your bases it on some documentation but even that is not guaranteed to remain as is.

@openhab/add-ons-maintainers your opinions are greatly appreciated here :-)
replies.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: @EvilPingu if no one veto's this (about nullable and json-mapping) one tonight and you looked into the latest remarks it should be ready to be merged! Thanks for your quick responses.
replies.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: @martinvw Afaik, our guidelines say that @NonNullByDefault must be used on classes and I do not recall any exception for JSON pojos. I'd hence say, it is fine (while not saying that your remark that it gives a false sense of security is wrong).
replies.author: kaikreuzer

timeline.bodyText: If you do believe fields will not be null, then better use the primitive types.

Would something terrible happen if you would support a duplicated device with the same serial number? It would simplify the code:
you could then just skip the findFirst and replace it by a forEach

timeline.bodyText: See remark above about using a naming strategy, given the size of the statement you might also consider creating some static method to initialize it.
timeline.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: I shorten the class names and extracts some methods
replies.author: EvilPingu

timeline.bodyText:
It might make more sense to just make this fields nullable, it seems you have "" a magical meaning instead.
If you want to leave, then position the literal first in String comparisons - that way if the String is null you won't get a NullPointerException, it'll just return false. source: PMD
timeline.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: EvilPingu

timeline.bodyText:
In E.4 of the coding guidelines we listed what kind of logging level should be used when. Error should only be used:

error logging should only be used to inform the user that something is tremendously wrong in his setup, the system cannot function normally anymore, and there is a need for immediate action.

Please change this to use the correct logging levels.
timeline.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: I think the correct way is to remove the logging and disable the thing. Is this correct?
replies.author: EvilPingu

replies.bodyText: Not really disabling, updating the thing status, calling updateStatus and I would see that this indicates a communication error, you could log the full stack trace to debug, but the most important is reporting to the user that something is wrong and passing the exception.getMessage() to the updateStatus could help for that.
replies.author: martinvw

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: EvilPingu
